comments.commentBody:
SEM: you can't solve a diagramless in across lite in any event, so presumably you are doing this on paper. one way to do this is print the puzzle from across lite, but under the print options, select "customize" and uncheck the grid. that'll print the clues only. or you could just resize the panes in the window so that the clues take up the whole space, and the grid goes away, and then find a piece of graph paper on which to actually solve.

as for finding old diagramlesses, the puzzle archive has links to all of the daily and second sunday puzzles, including diagramlesses. there is one every six weeks or so, which comes to 8 or 9 a year.

http://select.nytimes.com...
What's with the acrostic for Sunday (3/14) only showing printed on the bottom half of the vertical pdf page? Too small for my aged eyes. Can anything be done?

My mom's molasses spice cookies sell out every time. I brought them to a party a couple of weeks ago and a friend and her daughter ate the whole batch before I had a chance to get them out in the spread.

Molasses Cookies

3/4 c. butter
1 c. sugar + extra
1/4 c. molasses
1 egg
2 tsp. baking soda
2 c. flour
1/4 heaping tsp. ground cloves
1/4 heaping tsp. powdered ginger
1 tsp. cinnamon
1/2 tsp. salt

yield: between 2 and 3 dozen depending on the size of the cookie

Melt butter and cool. Add sugar, egg and molasses, and beat well. Sift together flour, baking soda, spices and salt. Add to first mixture. Mix well and chill in refrigerator for about an hour. After it's chilled, form the dough in 1 inch balls in your hand and roll the ball around in granulated sugar. Place on cookie sheets. Bake at 375 degrees for 8 minutes. They'll look a light golden color (i.e. not baked enough), but take them out anyway. Spatula them from the sheets to cooling racks; by the time they're cool enough to eat, they'll have firmed up and be amazing.

MAGIC PEANUT BUTTER COOKIES

These magically disappear, and just happen to be dairy- and gluten free! The recipe looks too simple to be correct, but that's really all there is to it. Just try not to eat all the batter before it bakes . . . starrskitchen.com

1 c. peanut butter (smooth or crunchy)
1 egg
1 c. sugar (fine or coarse raw sugar both work well.)
1 tsp. vanilla

Mix well and shape into 1" balls.
Bake 15 minutes at 300 degrees on ungreased parchment or silicon sheet. Cookies should not brown.
Let cool 5 minutes before carefully moving to cooling racks. These will firm up as they cool.

Options:
> before baking, roll balls in sugar, crushed peanuts, cocoa or coconut
> before baking, press large raisins, cherry halves, chunks of dried plums or big chocolate chips on top of each cookie.
> after baking, drizzle cookies with melted chocolate chips or roll in powdered sugar or cocoa.
> make sandwich cookies with melted chocolate chips or icing.

Yes there has been an offense re:whale meat and it will be prosecuted to the fullest. And, since we're on the whale subject, what has anyone done about the horrible pain the whales and sea life go through whenever the Navy decides to blast out sonic sound. We know seals and whales etc. hear because they communicate with sound. On this very day one can float in the waters of Wailea and hear the musical cacophony of whales talking to each other. All in the name of national defense? And, what about the multibillion Super Ferry that has been proven to be detrimental to ocean creatures particularly migrating whales of the Hawaiian Islands. Even tho the good citizens of Kauai put their lives on the line to successfully stop this monstrosity from mooring in their shores, there are plans to ignore and circumvent the EPA warnings. Last but not least, what about the sewage we dump regularly into the ocean and the run off from the use
of Round-Up. In my opinion, that product should be banned from this earth. If we are going to prosecute someone for providing food from a protected mammal then lets protect all the sea life from our arrogant abuse.

I have made this recipe for cake or cupcakes for every bake sale, publishing party since my kids were in nursery school. Now they are in middle school and high school and they make it themselves. It's from Moosewood Restaurant Cooks at Home. It's easy, tasty, and it has no eggs, so it's good for people with food allergies.

Six-Minute Chocolate Cake

1 and 1/2 cups unbleached white flour
1/3 c. unsweetened cocoa powder
1 tsp. baking soda
1/2 tsp. salt
1 c. sugar
1/2 c. vegetable oil
1 c. cold water or brewed coffee
2 tsp. pure vanilla extract
2 T. vinegar

To make the cake, preheat oven to 375 degrees.

Sift together the flour, cocoa, baking soda, salt, and sugar into an ungreased 8-inch squareor 9-inch round baking pan. In a 2 cup measuring cup, measure and mix together the oil, water or coffee, and vanilla. Pour the liquid ingredients into the baking pan and mix the batter with a fork or small whisk. When the batter is smooth, add the vinegar and stir quickly. There will be pale swirls in the batter where the baking soda and the vinegar are reacting. Stir just until the vinegar is evenly distributed throughout the batter. Bake for 25 to 30 minutes.

For cupcakes, bake at 375 degrees for 20 minutes. Makes 2 dozen.

The Andreja Premium by Quick Mill as adapted by Chris at Chris Coffee Service is terrific and the customer service has been beyond perfect.  I bought mine from Sweet Maria, a great site for equipment and green beans if you roast your own as I do, or you can buy direct.  Over $1000 but a nearly perfect home machine.

Triple Orange Chocolate Chunk Muffins

2 cups white whole wheat flour
1/3-cup firmly packed light-brown sugar
1/3-cup granulated sugar
1 ½ teaspoons baking powder
½ teaspoon baking soda
½ teaspoon salt
1/3 cup olive oil
¼ cup orange juice
¼ cup orange-flavored liqueur (such as Cointreau or Grand Marnier)
1 egg, lightly beaten or 1 vegan egg (1/4 tea + 2 T ground flax seed)
1 teaspoon grated orange peel
1 teaspoon vanilla
1 cup semisweet chocolate chunks cut from a block of chocolate (such as Ghirardelli or Callebaut)

Preheat oven to 400 degrees F. Line or grease ten 3 x 1 ¼-inch (3 ½- to 4-ounce) muffin cups. Or, if making mini muffins, line about 30-1 ½ x ¾-inch (2-ounce) muffin cups.

In a large bowl, stir together flour, sugars, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. In another bowl, stir together oil, juice, liqueur, egg, orange peel, and vanilla. Make a well in center of dry ingredients; add oil mixture and stir just to combine. Stir in chocolate chunks.

Spoon batter into prepared muffin cups; bake 15 – 20 minutes for regular and 13-14 minutes for minis, or until a cake tester inserted in center of one muffin comes out clean.

Remove muffin tin or tins to a wire rack. Cool slightly in pan before removing; finish cooling on rack. Serve warm, or cool completely, and store in an airtight container at room temperature. These muffins freeze well.
Whales are like dogs and cats in America. We prefer to cage, train and teach them to do tricks for our personal pleasure.

"but it all fell apart when we brought out a little box containing two small slices of chocolate cake leftover from the taping of the day before."

Good grief, what a dumb person, demanding the right to bring leftovers from the previous day to a restaurant.

Please sign and forward this Petition Against A-812 to support our Bake-In Rally.

Let your voice be heard with a commentary after signing.

http://www.ipetitions.com...

Support us by sharing this petition with your social media networks on Facebook, Linked-In, Stumble, etc.

Thank you!

Jean Lee (Bake-In organizing committee member, The Children's Workshop School parent)

Lemon Ginger Scones

Make some really good scones. Add chopped candied Ginger and lemon zest.

At my church's bake sales these sell out to the table workers before the sale opens.

Banning home made baked goods in schools is a travesty. Home made foods are always healthier and more economically viable for families than pre-packaged. Baking also promotes parent child interaction, literacy, math skills, nutrition and healthy eating.

If the stove top espresso maker make you happy, enjoy. But stove top espresso maker shots, as I have had with many friends' homes in Italy, really does not compare to a good hand pulled espresso. The Italians are not "wrong", but going for understandable convenience.

I use a La Pavoni lever machine. After years of practice, I can make great espresso. But the greatest quantum leap in quality comes from roasting my own beans (go to sweetmarias website). If not ready for home roasting, at least find a local roaster and use beans which were roasted yesterday...and try to buy fresh roasted beans weekly. The difference will shock you if you have been buying commercial roasts. The difference is not subtle, it will surprise you. Like fresh bread at a bakery, it will vary time to time, but there is pleasure in that.

Other comments say: Where are the stove-Top Espresso makers?

I agree with some of the above comments, that these little "Italians", the double boilers, are abscent from most discussions of good coffee, yet they make incredible coffee.

However, it's really not an espresso maker, exactly... even if our marketing pros tell us it is.

My tiny one has an amazing coffee to water ratio but still it's a Moka, or whatever other name, but not Espresso. Or an 'Italian' if you are in other part of Europe. Nobody is likely to make a MokaChino a la Starbucks, btw.

Al that said, I'll keep using my "Italian", with whatever beans. YUM! How about a review of these little, amazing, and inexpensive machines?
Its nice to have good equipment. However, you get more improvement in your coffee if you roast your own beans.

why makes it so complicated? just go out and get a good rating steam pressure machine like frances frances or other brands; no need to educated in italiano. and dont forget to pick up some frashly grained beans of your choice & voila your first cup of strong coffee without breaking your bank account...hehe!

First of all, Pop-Tarts? Is the world going insane?????? This is my "go-to, sell out everytime" bake sale favorite. Fast to make, and good for those with dairy allergies, nut allergies and vegans. It's actually a cake recipe developed during WWII during rationing, and uses vegetable oil, baking soda, baking powder, water and vinegar for leavening in place of butter and eggs. Growing up my mom called it "Crazy Chocolate Cake", but I've renamed it:

VEGAN CHOCOLATE CAKE

1 1/2 C. flour
3 T. cocoa
1 T. instant coffee
3/4 cup sugar
1 t. baking soda
1/2 t. salt
1/2 t. baking powder
1 t. white or apple cider vinegar
1 t. vanilla
5 T. vegetable oil (canola or even olive oil)
1 C. water

Preheat oven to 350. Grease and flour a loaf pan. Mix dry ingredients well. Add wet ingredients and mix well by hand until batter is smooth. Bake 45 minutes or until a toothpick comes out clean. Cool on a rack then cut into 1" slices. If desired, sift confectioner's sugar over loaf cake before slicing.

This concentration on the machine is slightly exaggerated. A much more significant part of a good coffee is the beans being used, its freshness, how fine it's ground, how tightly it is tamped down. What is important about the machines is the pressure they are able to produce. The more pressure, the finer grind and more flavor is possible. I used the inexpensive Krupp for many years and got good coffee out of it, than found a Breville on sale at Bloomingdale's (not cheap), and no store made espresso competes with the espresso I make at home. Curiously, the most satisfying beans (to me) was an Organic Ethiopian (French Roast) from the San Francisco Bay Coffee Co. via Costco that cannot be found anymore.

Unfortunately, I do not carry partially hydrogenated oils, high fructose corn syrup, or artificial flavorings in my home kitchen. If the schools are insisting that the flours, sugars, and butter used in homemade baked goods be thrown out the window in favor of these ingredients, which they can "control" and measure against certain "guidelines", then I, a home baker, cannot compete. Why not do away with the bake sale altogether, then? Have a dance-off instead, or have children raise fruit and vegetables which they can then sell, if we are so concerned about students' health. The foods currently served in school cafeterias, and those the Dept of Ed is trying to promote at bake sales would never be served in my home, for my family. Although my baked goods may not comply with their health standards, the foods they offer and promote in schools do not comply with mine.
That being said, here is a recipe for carrot cake I adapted from Cooking Light magazine (no affiliation, I just subscribe to their magazine). I decreased the original recipe's quantity of sugar in the frosting. And I bake these as cupcakes instead of a cake if I am taking them to a bake sale. I made little notes for the changes I usually make when baking this. Nutritional information can be found on Cooking Light's website.

Fruity Carrot Cake
• Cake:
• 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour (about 6 3/4 ounces)
• 1 1/3 cups granulated sugar
• 1/2 cup sweetened flaked coconut
• 1/3 cup chopped pecans (I don't put these in because I don't like nuts in my cake!)
• 2 teaspoons baking soda
• 1 teaspoon salt (I actually use about ½ teaspoon because my salt is salty)
• 2 teaspoons ground cinnamon (I also use ground cloves, nutmeg, etc and throw it all in- no measurements)
• 3 tablespoons canola oil
• 2 large eggs
• 2 cups grated carrot (If I have apples or pears lying around, I do 1 cup grated apple/pear and 1 cup carrot)
• 1 1/2 cups canned crushed pineapple, drained
• I add raisins and dried cranberries
• Cooking spray
•
Frosting:
• 2 tablespoons butter, softened
• 1 (8-ounce) block 1/3-less-fat cream cheese, softened
• 3 cups powdered or confectioners sugar (I NEVER use this much sugar!! Maybe 1 ½ cups, maybe 2, depending on my mood)
• 2 teaspoons vanilla extract
• Additional grated carrot (optional)
• I also add cinnamon, ground cloves, nutmeg to this frosting. It makes the cake look pretty and it tastes better.

Preparation
Preheat oven to 350°.
To prepare cake, lightly spoon flour into dry measuring cups; level with a knife. Combine flour, sugar, coconut, pecans, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon/spices in a large bowl; stir well with a whisk. Combine oil and eggs; stir well. Stir egg mixture, grated carrot, and pineapple into flour mixture. Spoon batter into a 13 x 9-inch baking pan coated with cooking spray. Bake at 350° for 35 minutes or until a wooden pick inserted in the center comes out clean. Cool completely on a wire rack. **If making cupcakes, divide the batter between 20-24 cupcake tins lined with liners. Bake until golden brown, or until wooden toothpick comes out clean, about 35 min.
To prepare frosting, combine butter and cream cheese in a large bowl. Beat with a mixer at medium speed until smooth. Beat in powdered sugar, vanilla, and spices just until smooth. Spread frosting over top of cake/cupcakes. Garnish each serving with grated carrot, if desired, or sprinkle with your favorite spice.

I have a collection of all sorts of discarded coffee makers, from the beautifully crafted Alessi stainless steel stovetop model to the $5 clunky-cute Bialetti roughly cast aluminum contraption that every Italian owns. However, they are all now on a basement shelf, unlikely to be used again. After switching to the Nespresso system, I save myself (and my spouse) from all the fuss/mess/noise of grinding, measuring, tamping--etc.--for what was always a second rate cup of espresso. It was a like a nice Italian sports car: when it worked well (about once a month and when you least expected it to), it was a lot of fun, but most of the time it was one big headache. If you live alone and have nothing but time and patience for pointless rituals that rival those of the papacy, keep the old stove top models. For me, I've finally become a true coffee secularist and have join the ranks of Nespresso.  Although the system is more expensive up front and over time (about double the cost per cup), the results are downright Germanic in their precision, quality, and reliability. No mess, no fuss, less time, much less noisy than a grinder, and by far the best coffee I've ever produced, day in, day out. Also, for foaming milk, the Nespresso areocinio is by far the greatest invention. No more disappointing results. It produces exactly the same amount of generous foam, every time, automatically. Clean up is easy as well. While I wish the coffee cartridges were available in grocery stores, shipments arrive 24 hours after order. The only downside is that I nearly tripled my daily coffee intake--it's that good. Also, it's very fast, which is essential for dinner parties. I can pop out single espresso shots in under 10 second each.  When I need extra storage space, I'll toss out all my old espresso pots soon, saving only the Alessi as an inspiring example of 20th century contemporary sculpture.

Lemon bars. These are the best, even against your favorite bakery.

(preheat oven to 350 degrees)

Into one cup softened unsalted butter beat one half cup powdered sugar. Gradually mix in two cups of flour. Blend in the zest of one lemon. Spread dough across the bottom of a 13 x 9 pan. Bake for 25-30 minutes until light brown.

As the crust finishes baking, pour 2/3 cup fresh lemon juice (Meyers are even better) into two cups of sugar. This dissolves the sugar wonderfully. Beat four eggs, add 1 tsp baking powder, 1/2 tsp salt, then pour in the lemon sugar mixture while blending. Pour the mixture on top of the hot crust, and return to the oven. Bake for 15 minutes or until bubbly and lightly browned. Cool completely on rack, sprinkle with powdered sugar.

For the price of one upscale bakery lemon bar, you've got an entire batch. These lemon bars also have mystical properties. They definitely win friends and influence enemies.

http://restlesschef.blogspot.com

Peanut Blossoms, a perfect combination of chocolate and peanut butter, is always a big hit. This recipe comes from River Road Recipes II, A Second Helping, by the Junior League of Baton Rouge.

Peanut Blossoms (Mrs. John F. Davis, Jr.)

1/2 cup shortening or margarine
1/2 cup brown sugar
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1/2 cup smooth peanut butter
1 egg
2 tablespoons milk
1 teaspoon vanilla
1 - 3/4 cups flour
1 teaspoon soda
1/2 teaspoon salt
Granulated sugar
Chocolate kisses

Cream together the shortening or margarine, sugars, peanut butter, egg, milk and vanilla. Sift flour, soda, and salt together. Add to creamed mixture. Make heaping teaspoons of dough into balls. Roll in granulated sugar. Put on ungreased cookie sheet. Bake at 350 degrees until lightly browned, about 10 - 15 minutes. As cookies come out of oven, stick a chocolate kiss in center, they will crack a little. Makes 5 dozen.

My notes: I line the baking sheet with parchment. Also, make sure you unwrap the kisses beforehand, since you have to work quickly when the cookies come out of the oven.

"Best pizza"? Come on! That depends on the weather, the time of year, your age, your bankroll, and whether your sinuses are acting up. But in all of New York, there are more opportunities for truly inspiring pizza than anywhere else I've had the joy or pain to live. New Haven? Very good. Chicago? Paisane! But in New York there's a new joy around every corner. Kinda like watching skirt lengths vary with the seasons--why would you bother anywhere else in the US?

I hear both the "bunnies are cute" and the "get over it" side, and I recall from childhood eating rabbit that my older relatives had hunted, gutted, and cooked. It was gamy for my immature palate, but I understood that it was something people ate. Now I'm no longer a child, and I accept the moral responsibility of adulthood. As Ralph Waldo Emerson noted, "You have just dined, and however scrupulously the slaughterhouse is concealed in the graceful distance of miles, there is complicity." Slicing and dicing which species are too cuddly and which are acceptable on the dinner plate is the ethical equivalent of having your pate and eating it. Either you kill to eat, or you don't. As for me, the bunny has nothing to fear.

For Italian filled doughnuts quite tony,
You can't improve on Bomboloni.
Fillings you can't match?
Try a chocolate ganache,
Kids choose 'em in lieu of a Pony.
